授業目的: この授業では漫画の歴史、そして漫画が日本の文化、又は海外の文化に与える影響と与えられた影響について話し合う。漫画と昔の絵巻、木版画などの芸術表現との関係を考え、現代のアニメや実写映画といった表現との関係も考える。漫画は日本の現代社会の中でどのような存在でどの立場にあるかを考え、漫画が日本国内だけでなく海外でも人気であり続ける理由を探る。まずは「マンガ」というものについて考え、初期の漫画とその前身の歴史をふまえ、それからおよその時代順に北沢楽天や岡本一平などの新聞漫画から２１世紀の最新のストーリー漫画まで取り上げていく。
到達目標: 受講者は漫画というメディアについての知識を深め、日本の歴史と大衆文化の中での漫画の立場をよりよく理解する。そして、漫画の世界で最も影響力があり個性的で優れた漫画家と作品に精通するようになる。また日本語を読む練習を兼ねて、漫画の内容と構成に関する用語を勉強する機会にもなる。最後に受講生は日本美術史からのマンガの由来、物語性のある芸術としての進化、世界中で人気が隆盛となり、そして最近の発展について語れるようになる。
授業方法: Face to Face. Lectures, group discussions, and student presentations.

第1回: Paintings and Illustrated Scrolls: Composition, Style, and Content

READ: Koyama-Richard, Brigitte. “The Magic of the Scroll: From the Earliest Caricatures to the Onset of the Comic Strip.” One Thousand Years of Manga, Flammarion, 2007, p. 6-7
READ: Salel, Stephen. The Art Historical Precedents of Modern Japanese Comics. Honolulu Museum of Art, Part 1, 2020
BEGIN: Research journal assignment
第2回: Early Manga: Woodblock Printing and Illustrated Books

READ: “Japanese Illustrated Handscrolls,” Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History, by Anna Willmann, Department of Asian Art, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2012
READ: Watanabe, Masako. “Storytelling in Japanese Art.” The Art of Japanese Storytelling, The Museum of Metropolitan Art, 2011, pp. 3-47
READ: “Chōjū giga.” Himoji, Kanagawa University
READ: “Shigisan engi.” Himoji, Kanagawa University
READ: Salel, Stephen. The Art Historical Precedents of Modern Japanese Comics. Honolulu Museum of Art, Parts 2 & 3, 2020
CONTINUE: Research journal assignment
第3回: Early Manga: Woodblock Printing and Illustrated Books (cont.)

READ: Salel, Stephen. The Art Historical Precedents of Modern Japanese Comics. Honolulu Museum of Art, Parts 4 & 5, 2020
READ: Araki, James T. “Otogi-Zōshi and Nara Ehon: A Field of Study in Fluctuation.” Monumenta Nipponica, vol. 36, no. 1, Sophia University, 1981, pp. 1-20
CONTINUE: Research journal assignment
第4回:
READ: Berndt, Jaqueline. “Pictures that Come to Life: The Hokusai Manga.” 2017, pp. 21-27
READ: Forrer, Matthi. “Hokusai as an Illustrator of Books: The Artist as Represented in the Pulverer Collection.” The World of the Japanese Illustrated Book: The Gerhard Pulverer Collection
READ: Yonemura, Ann. “Art Meets Commerce: Illustrated Books and the Japanese Publishing Enterprise in the Edo Period and Beyond.” The World of the Japanese Illustrated Book: The Gerhard Pulverer Collection
READ: Kern, Adam L. “Kabuki Plays on Page–and Comicbook Pictures on Stage–in Edo-Period Japan.”
CONTINUE: Research journal assignment
第5回:
READ: Kusahara, Machiko. “Utsushi-e and the Magic Lantern: An Archaeology of The Moving Image.”
READ: Lamarre, Thomas. “Magic Lantern, Dark Precursor of Animation.” Animation, vol. 6, no. 127, 2011
READ: Berndt, Jaqueline. “Traditions of Contemporary Manga (1): Relating Comics to Premodern Art.” SIGNs: Studies in Graphic Narratives, 2007
READ: Stewart, Ronald. “Manga History: Shimizu Isao and Miyamoto Hirohito on Japan’s First Modern Manga.” Comics Forum, June 2014
CONTINUE: Research journal assignment
第6回:
READ: Duus, Peter. “‘Punch Pictures’: Localising Punch in Meiji Japan.” Asian Punches: A Transcultural Affair, 2013, pp. 307 – 335
READ: Illerbrun, Kurt. “The Japanese Political Cartoon: Development and Decline,” pp. 8 – 29
READ: Duus, Peter. “Presidential Address: Weapons of the Weak, Weapons of the Strong.” The Journal of Asian Studies, Vol. 60, No. 4, November 2001, pp. 965 – 997
CONTINUE: Research journal assignment
第7回:
READ: Exner, Eike. “Prologue.” Comics and the Origins of Manga: A Revisionist History, 2022, pp.13-24
READ: Van Lente, Fred and Ryan Dunlavey. “Comic Book History of Comics.” vol. 2, no. 3, IDW Publishing, February 2018, pp. 1 – 12, 19
READ: Fusanosuke Natsume. “Takahashi Rumiko and the Turning Point in the History of Manga and Anime.” The Comics Journal, translated by Jon Holt and Fukuda Teppei, 11 November 2021
CONTINUE: Research journal assignment
第8回:
READ: Ito, Kinko. “Manga In Japanese History.” Japanese Visual Culture: Explorations in the World of Manga and Anime, 2008, pp.26-47
READ: Schodt, Frederik L. “Manga! Manga!: the World of Japanese Comics.” New York: Kodansha USA, Inc., 2013, pp. 5-27
CONTINUE: Research journal assignment
第9回:
READ: McCloud, Scott. “Understanding Manga.” Making Comics: Storytelling Secrets of Comics, Manga, and Graphic Novels, 2006, pp. 215 – 222
READ: McCloud, Scott. “Blood in the Gutter.” Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art, 1993, pp. 60-93
READ: Natsume Fusanosuke. “The Construction of Panels (koma) in Manga.” Why is Manga so Interesting? Its Grammar and Expression, Translated by Jon Holt and Teppei Fukuda, ImageText
READ: Cohn, Neil. “Japanese Visual Language: The Structure of Manga.” 2007
COMPLETE: Research journal assignment
第10回:
READ: “The Trend toward Affirmation of War: ‘Norakuro’” by Kato Hidetoshi, The Japan Interpreter
READ: Tagawa Suiho. “Norakuro and His Howlin’ Commandos.” Kramers Ergot 6. Sammy Harkham. Oakland: Buenaventura Press, 2006. 189 – 218. Print
READ: Nakazawa, Shunsuke. “The Forgotten History of Japanese Comics before Osamu Tezuka and Tank Tankuro’s Maverick World.” Tank Tankuro: Prewar Works, 1934-1953, Press Pop, Inc., 2011, pp. VIII-XV
READ: Sakamoto Gajō. “Tank Tankurō: The Prewar Works, 1934-1953.” (October 1935), Press Pop Inc, pp. 1-31
第11回:
READ: Berndt, Jaqueline. “Reflections: Writing Comics into Art History in Contemporary Japan.” Konsthistorisk tidskrift/Journal of Art History, vol. 86, no. 1, 2017, pp. 67-74
READ: Tezuka Osamu. “New Treasure Island.” Translated by Greg Baker. Digital Manga, Inc. 1947 (2015)
READ: Holmberg, Ryan. The Comics Journal, “Emonogatari in the Age of Comics, 1948 – 1957,” by Ryan Holmberg, November 17, 2011
第12回: From Fan Fiction to Manga Bestsellers
PREPARE: for optional research presentations (content subject to change according to participation)
第13回: Optional research presentations (content subject to change according to participation)

COMPLETE: Annotated bibliography assignment

トピック.授業外学習2:
Links to lectures, reading assignments, and other study materials will be provided online.

Students will be required to read articles on manga, Japanese art and culture, history, and current events. Students will be expected to complete all reading and writing assignments prior to the beginning of the following class, in preparation for lectures and group discussions. Students will be required to keep a journal to respond to independently selected examples of manga and its various elements (narrative, art & design, cultural relevance & use, etc.). Journals will be used in class discussions.

受講生は予習にマンガ、日本美術、日本の文化、歴史、時事などについての記事を読む。授業で取り上げられたマンガ、またはその一部も読む。学生は毎週各自で選んだ漫画、またはその一部を分析して、授業用の日記を書く。授業で日記の内容について発表する。

DP・CPを意識して本授業科目の学修を進めることで、各学部・研究科の期待する能力が養成されます。

評価.備考Note0: Students are expected to attend all class meetings unless absent for a valid reason such as illness, injury, or emergency. In such cases, please contact the lecturer directly. Late submissions of assignments will not be accepted, unless under the aforementioned circumstances.

name: 【300】総合日本学習科目（マンガ文化史）／JSC Manga: A Cultural History
担当者: ベイカー　Ｏ．　Ｙ．（BAKER OMAR YUSEF）
成績評価備考:
備考　Note
Students are expected to prepare for each lesson by completing previously assigned readings, etc. Students will be asked to speak and write about the contents of the reading assignments and previous lectures in class. Students will also be required to keep a research journal in preparation for in class discussions and the final writing assignment. Consistent attendance for lectures and group discussions is expected. Details regarding the weekly and end of semester writing assignments will be explained during the first class meeting. Students will be required to give short presentations or lead discussions on topics chosen from their research journals.
